div1.head: PETITION.
div1.p: To the Commissioners under the act of Congress approved the 16th of April, 1862, entitled "An act for the release of certain persons held to service or labor in the District of Columbia."

Your Petitioner, William B. Magruder of Brookville Montgomery Co Md. by this his petition in writing, represents and states, that he is a person loyal to the United States, who, at the time of the passage of the said act of Congress, held a claim to service or labor against a female person of African descent of the name of Mary Ellen Campbell for and during the life of said Mary Ellen Campbell and that by said act of Congress said Mary Ellen Campbell was discharged and freed of and from all claim of your petitioner to such service or labor; that at the time of said discharge said Mary Ellen Campbell was of the age of Eighteen years and of the personal description following:Here describe the person, so as to identify him or her; and if there be more than one slave, describe each one separately. of Dark Brown Color, five feet Three inches high (5 ft. 3 in) well built—full face pleasant countenance, rather thick lips

That your petitioner acquired his claim to the aforesaid service or labor of said Mary Ellen Campbell in manner following:Here state how the claim was acquired, when, from whom, and for what price or consideration; and, if held under any written evidence of title, make exhibit thereof, or refer to the public record where the same may be found. I purchased her mother of Nathan Cook of Montgomery Co Md. Said Cook became possessed of her by his wife who was the deponents Sister. and the Said Mary Ellen was born my Slave

That your petitioner's claim to the service or labor of said Mary Ellen Campbell was, at the time of said discharge therefrom, of the value of One thousand dollars in money.Here state such facts, if any there be, touching the value of the petitioner's claim to the service or labor of the person, as may enhance the same, and also such facts, if any, touching the moral, mental, and bodily infirmities or defects of said person, as impair the value of the petitioner's claim to such service or labor, and conclude such statement with an averment that the petitioner knows of no other infirmities or defects of said person which impair the value of petitioner's claim to such service or labor, and that he believes none other to exist. If the petitioner specify no such infirmity or defect, then his statement touching the value of his claim should conclude with an averment that he has no knowledge of any such infirmity or defect.Your petitioner avers that the said Mary Ellen by reason of her intelligence, honesty industry, and physical ability, was very valuable either as a house servant or cook, and he has no knowledge whatever of any moral, mental or bodily infirmity or defect which would impair the value of your petitioners claim to her service or labor.

Your petitioner hereby declares that he bears true and faithful allegiance to the Government of the United States, and that he has not borne arms against the United States in the present rebellion, nor in any way given aid or comfort thereto.

And your petitioner further states and alleges, that he has not brought said Mary Ellen into the District of Columbia since the passage of said act of Congress; and that, at the time of the passage thereof, said Mary Ellen was held to service or labor therein under and by virtue of your petitioner's claim to such service or labor.

Your petitioner further states and alleges, that his said claim to the service or labor of said Mary Ellen does not originate in or by virtue of any transfer heretofore made by any person who has in any manner aided or sustained the present rebellion against the Government of the United States.

And your petitioner prays the said Commissioners to investigate and determine the validity of his said claim to the service or labor of said Mary Ellen herein above set forth; and if the same be found to be valid, that they appraise and apportion the value of said claim in money, and report the same to the Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, in conformity to the provisions of said act of Congress.

div1.head: [Form of the Oath for the Verification of the Petition.]
div1.dateline:
District of Columbia,
Washington County, ss.

div2.p: I, William B Magruder being duly sworn, do depose and say, that all the several matters and things which are set forth and stated in the foregoing petition, as of my own knowledge, are true in substance and in fact; and that all the several other matters and things therein set forth and stated, as from the information of others, I believe to be true in substance and in fact.
Sworn to and subscribed before me this 21st day of May A. D. 1862.
div2.closer:
(Signed by) John S Hollingshead
Notary Public
